headline: Dubai Air Show opens as local airlines likely seek more jets and defense remains a regional worry
summary: The biennial Dubai Air Show opened Monday as hometown airlines Emirates and FlyDubai likely look to increase their fleets off record earnings and unending demand for flights through this East-West travel hub.  The air show will also see renewed interest in flying taxis, something the sheikhdom long has promised and now hopes to deliver on next year.  Emirates, the state-owned flagship airline of Dubai, earned annual profits of $5.2 billion in the last fiscal year and passenger numbers remain record-breaking at Dubai International Airport, the world's busiest for international travel.

content.title: Dubai Air Show opens as local airlines likely seek more jets and defense remains a regional worry
content.summary: The biennial Dubai Air Show opened Monday as hometown airlines Emirates and FlyDubai likely look to increase their fleets off record earnings and unending demand for flights through this East-West travel hub.  The air show will also see renewed interest in flying taxis, something the sheikhdom long has promised and now hopes to deliver on next year.  Emirates, the state-owned flagship airline of Dubai, earned annual profits of $5.2 billion in the last fiscal year and passenger numbers remain record-breaking at Dubai International Airport, the world's busiest for international travel.

headline: Emirates Orders 65 More Boeing 777X Airplanes
summary: Boeing [NYSE: BA] and Emirates announced today the world's largest international airline has placed its third order for 777X airplanes to fuel future expansion and meet growing travel demand. The new order for 65 777-9 passenger jets was announced during a signing at the Dubai Airshow.

content.title: Emirates Orders 65 More Boeing 777X Airplanes
content.summary: Boeing [NYSE: BA] and Emirates announced today the world's largest international airline has placed its third order for 777X airplanes to fuel future expansion and meet growing travel demand. The new order for 65 777-9 passenger jets was announced during a signing at the Dubai Airshow.

headline: Dubai Air Show opens as Emirates announces major Boeing purchase
summary: The biennial Dubai Air Show opened Monday with hometown airline Emirates ordering 65 Boeing 777-9 aircraft, as the carrier looks to increase its fleets off record earnings and unending demand for flights through this East-West travel hub.  The airline did not immediately give a value for the deal with Boeing and GE Engines.  The air show will also see renewed interest in flying taxis, something the sheikhdom long has promised and now hopes to deliver on next year.

content.title: Dubai Air Show opens as Emirates announces major Boeing purchase
content.summary: The biennial Dubai Air Show opened Monday with hometown airline Emirates ordering 65 Boeing 777-9 aircraft, as the carrier looks to increase its fleets off record earnings and unending demand for flights through this East-West travel hub.  The airline did not immediately give a value for the deal with Boeing and GE Engines.  The air show will also see renewed interest in flying taxis, something the sheikhdom long has promised and now hopes to deliver on next year.

thumbnail.caption: FILE - An Emirates Airlines Boeing 777 lands at Logan International Airport in Boston, March 10, 2014. (AP Photo/Michael Dwyer, File)

headline: Boeing (BA): Examining Valuation After Recent Share Price Slowdown
summary: Boeing (BA) shares have drifted in recent weeks, slightly underperforming the broader market. The stock is down about 9% over the past month, although its year-to-date return remains positive. Investors are weighing the company’s mixed results as the industry continues to face ongoing challenges. See our latest analysis for Boeing. Boeing’s share price has lost steam recently, shrugging off some earlier momentum despite the company turning positive for the year. While recent news headlines...

headline: Emirates announces order of 65 Boeing 777-9s with list price of $38 billion at Dubai Air Show
summary: The biennial Dubai Air Show opened Monday with hometown airline Emirates ordering 65 of Boeing's upcoming 777-9 aircraft, as the carrier looks to increase its fleets off record earnings and unending demand for flights through this East-West travel hub.  Emirates valued the deal with Boeing and GE Engines at $38 billion at list prices, although airlines often negotiate lower prices in major orders.

content.title: Emirates announces order of 65 Boeing 777-9s with list price of $38 billion at Dubai Air Show
content.summary: The biennial Dubai Air Show opened Monday with hometown airline Emirates ordering 65 of Boeing's upcoming 777-9 aircraft, as the carrier looks to increase its fleets off record earnings and unending demand for flights through this East-West travel hub.  Emirates valued the deal with Boeing and GE Engines at $38 billion at list prices, although airlines often negotiate lower prices in major orders.

thumbnail.caption: Stephanie Pope, President and CEO of Boeing Commercial Airplanes, left, Sheikh Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum, President, Dubai Civil Aviation Authority and Chairman of Emirates airlines, centre, and Mahendra Nair, group vice-president GE Aerospace, pose during a press conference on the opening day of the Dubai Air Show, United Arab Emirates, Monday, Nov. 17, 2025. (AP Photo/Altaf Qadri)

headline: Ethiopian Airlines Commits to Order 11 Boeing 737 MAX Airplanes
summary: Boeing (NYSE: BA) and Ethiopian Airlines announced today Africa's largest carrier has committed to purchase 11 additional 737 MAX jets. The agreement for 11 737-8, signed at the Dubai Airshow, will enable Ethiopian Airlines to grow its regional and international networks and expand its Addis Ababa hub.

content.title: Ethiopian Airlines Commits to Order 11 Boeing 737 MAX Airplanes
content.summary: Boeing (NYSE: BA) and Ethiopian Airlines announced today Africa's largest carrier has committed to purchase 11 additional 737 MAX jets. The agreement for 11 737-8, signed at the Dubai Airshow, will enable Ethiopian Airlines to grow its regional and international networks and expand its Addis Ababa hub.

thumbnail.caption: Ethiopian Airlines Commits to Order 11 Additional Boeing 737 MAX Airplanes. Credit: Boeing.

headline: Emirates places $38bn order for 65 Boeing 777-9s at Dubai Air Show
summary: The airline plans to begin receiving deliveries in 2027, as it expands its fleet to meet growing demand through Dubai, one of the world’s busiest travel hubs.View on euronews

content.title: Emirates places $38bn order for 65 Boeing 777-9s at Dubai Air Show
content.summary: The airline plans to begin receiving deliveries in 2027, as it expands its fleet to meet growing demand through Dubai, one of the world’s busiest travel hubs.View on euronews

headline: Emirates announces an order of 65 Boeing 777-9s with list price of $38 billion at Dubai Air Show
summary: The biennial Dubai Air Show opened on Monday with hometown airline Emirates ordering 65 of Boeing's upcoming 777-9 aircraft, as the carrier looks to increase its fleets off record earnings and unending demand for flights through this East-West travel hub.  Emirates valued the deal with Boeing and GE Engines at $38 billion at list prices, although airlines often negotiate lower prices in major orders.  The announcement brings the total of Boeing 777-9s on order for Emirates to 270, making it Boeing's largest customer for the aircraft, even as the plane has suffered repeated delays in entering service.

content.title: Emirates announces an order of 65 Boeing 777-9s with list price of $38 billion at Dubai Air Show
content.summary: The biennial Dubai Air Show opened on Monday with hometown airline Emirates ordering 65 of Boeing's upcoming 777-9 aircraft, as the carrier looks to increase its fleets off record earnings and unending demand for flights through this East-West travel hub.  Emirates valued the deal with Boeing and GE Engines at $38 billion at list prices, although airlines often negotiate lower prices in major orders.  The announcement brings the total of Boeing 777-9s on order for Emirates to 270, making it Boeing's largest customer for the aircraft, even as the plane has suffered repeated delays in entering service.

thumbnail.caption: Stephanie Pope, President and CEO of Boeing Commercial Airplanes, left, and Sheikh Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum, President, Dubai Civil Aviation Authority and Chairman of Emirates airlines, sign an agreement to order 65 additional Boeing 777X aircrafts during a press conference on the opening day of the Dubai Air Show, United Arab Emirates, Monday, Nov. 17, 2025. (AP Photo/Altaf Qadri)

headline: Air Senegal Commits to First Boeing 737 MAX Order
summary: Boeing [NYSE: BA] and Air Senegal announced today the West African carrier has committed to order nine 737 MAX airplanes. When final, the 737 MAX order will be the airline's largest-ever fleet purchase – and first Boeing airplane order since 2004 – as it looks to expand service regionally and internationally.

content.title: Air Senegal Commits to First Boeing 737 MAX Order
content.summary: Boeing [NYSE: BA] and Air Senegal announced today the West African carrier has committed to order nine 737 MAX airplanes. When final, the 737 MAX order will be the airline's largest-ever fleet purchase – and first Boeing airplane order since 2004 – as it looks to expand service regionally and internationally.

thumbnail.caption: Air Senegal's largest commitment to purchase nine 737-8 jets. Credit: Boeing.

headline: Trump's Boeing Support Makes Airbus Work Harder: Scherer
summary: Christian Scherer, chief executive officer of Airbus' commercial aircraft business, discusses orders and competition from Boeing, the rival US planemaker whose sales have beaten those of its European rival this year. President Donald Trump has made aircraft orders a prominent part of his campaign to pare the US trade deficit.

content.title: Trump's Boeing Support Makes Airbus Work Harder: Scherer
content.description: Christian Scherer, chief executive officer of Airbus' commercial aircraft business, discusses orders and competition from Boeing, the rival US planemaker whose sales have beaten those of its European rival this year. President Donald Trump has made aircraft orders a prominent part of his campaign to pare the US trade deficit.
content.summary: Christian Scherer, chief executive officer of Airbus' commercial aircraft business, discusses orders and competition from Boeing, the rival US planemaker whose sales have beaten those of its European rival this year. President Donald Trump has made aircraft orders a prominent part of his campaign to pare the US trade deficit.

headline: Boeing Distribution launches unified ecommerce platform
summary: Boeing [NYSE: BA] announced a key milestone in its ongoing journey to modernize and integrate its distribution businesses with the launch of a new, unified ecommerce website. The new platform brings together Boeing Distribution's portfolio of products and services into one streamlined digital destination, simplifying how customers and suppliers connect, transact and grow with the company.

content.title: Boeing Distribution launches unified ecommerce platform

The new platform brings together Boeing Distribution's portfolio of products and services into one streamlined digital destination, simplifying how customers and suppliers connect, transact and grow with the company.

thumbnail.caption: Boeing Distribution launches unified ecommerce platform

headline: Emirates orders 65 more Boeing 777X planes despite delays
summary: Emirates, the Middle East's biggest airline, topped up its order of Boeing 777X planes on Monday despite years of delays, delivering a vote of confidence to the US manufacturer at the Dubai Airshow.Emirates, already the biggest customer for the Boeing 777, now has 270 777X, 10 777 freighters and 35 Boeing 787s on order.

content.title: Emirates orders 65 more Boeing 777X planes despite delays
content.summary: Emirates, the Middle East's biggest airline, topped up its order of Boeing 777X planes on Monday despite years of delays, delivering a vote of confidence to the US manufacturer at the Dubai Airshow.Emirates, already the biggest customer for the Boeing 777, now has 270 777X, 10 777 freighters and 35 Boeing 787s on order.

thumbnail.caption: The Emirates order delivered a vote of confidence to the US manufacturer on day one of the Dubai Airshow (Giuseppe CACACE)
